questions.text: The toxin produced by the organisms shown below acts via?
questions.solution:
The given image shows gram-positive rods with club-shaped ends, beaded appearance, and a¬†Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement indicative of¬†Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

The toxin produced by the bacteria - diphtheria toxin -¬†inhibits polypeptide chain elongation and protein synthesis by inactivating the elongation factor-2 (EF-2) by ADP ribosylation. It has two fragments - fragment B helps in binding of the toxin to host cells and fragment A inactivates EF-2.¬†

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: The cornerstone of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is:
questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is IV fluids.

The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion and thereby shock. So, the supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids remains the primary modality of treatment in these patients. And often patients respond well to supportive management.

Platelet transfusion is limited to patients with severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3) and active bleeding.

FFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred treatment modality in dengue.

Warning signs in dengue include 

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion)
  • Mucosal bleeding
  • Lethargy or restlessness
  • Hepatomegaly >2 cm
  • Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet count

Inpatient management is advised to all patient of dengue with warning signs.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not needed in the patient postoperatively?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a woman presenting with hypopituitarism following trans-sphenoidal resection. Mineralocorticoid supplementation is not needed postoperatively as it is regulated by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and not by ACTH. Therefore, mineralocorticoid levels would remain intact despite ACTH deficiency.

Thyroid hormone, estradiol, and glucocorticoid supplementation are needed in this patient as their secretion is regulated by anterior pituitary hormones.

Features of hypopituitarism include growth abnormalities in children with a growth hormone deficiency, insufficient levels of gonadotropins leading to menstrual irregularities, infertility in women and reduced sexual function, infertility and loss of secondary sexual characteristics in men. TSH deficiency leads to stunted growth in children and features of hypothyroidism in both children and adults. ACTH deficiency leads to secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Polyuria and polydipsia may be seen and indicate a loss of vasopressin secretion in posterior pituitary lesions.

The following hormones must be replaced post-hypophysectomy:

Trophic hormone deficit

Hormone Replacement

ACTH

Hydrocortisone, cortisone acetate, prednisone 
TSH

L-thyroxine (75–150 µg daily)
FSH/LH
Males: Testosterone
 
Females: 

For fertility: menopausal gonadotropins, hCG

Post-menopausal women: Conjugated estrogen, progesterone
GH

Somatotropin
Vasopressin

Intranasal desmopressin

questions.text: A case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is detected to have metastasis in the lungs. It is considered as stage _____.
questions.solution:
Metastases in the lungs are considered stage III GTN (gestational trophoblastic neoplasia) in FIGO classification.

International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) staging for GTN is as follows:

Stage Description
I GTN confined to the uterus

II

GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures    

(adnexa, vagina, broad ligament)
III GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
IV All other metastatic sites i.e. kidney, liver, brain, bowel, etc.

The chest X-ray below shows lung metastasis - stage III GTN. 

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to the aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblast cells. It includes invasive mole, gestational choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumors, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of GTN: 

  • Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer
  • Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer
  • Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more
  • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma 

Treatment for low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

questions.text: The given USG of lung shows:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the seashore sign seen in M-mode imaging of the normal lung.

M-mode is defined as the time-motion display of the ultrasound wave along a chosen ultrasound line. With M-Mode, even rapid motions can be displayed, measured, and recorded.

In the M-mode of USG, the motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal ‘waves', and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the ‘sand’. The resultant picture is one that resembles waves crashing in onto the sand and is therefore called the ‘seashore sign’ and is present in a normal lung.

Option A: Stratosphere sign or barcode sign is a finding in the M-mode seen as parallel horizontal lines above and below the pleural line. This is seen in pneumothorax.

Option C: There is no named sign called troposphere sign.

Option D: Mirror image artifact is seen when there is a highly reflective surface (eg: Diaphragm) in the path of the primary beam.

questions.text: Which of the following about Œ≥ùõø T-cells is incorrect:

choices.text: Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
Need  antigen processing and presentation for it recognition

questions.solution:
γùõø T-cells do not need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition.

There are two types of T cells: γùõø T-cells and αβ T-cells.

The functions of γùõø T-cells:

  • Provide protection against mycobacteria by direct killing of infected macrophages
  • Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
  • Plays a role in maintaining self-tolerance
  • Capable of recognising and lysing diverse cancers in an MHC-unrestricted manner

αβ T-cells have MHC restricted action.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with red arrow
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the slide is the outer plexiform layer of the retina.¬†

The outer plexiform layer¬†(outer synaptic layer) is present between the outer nuclear layer and the inner nuclear layer.¬†This layer stains lightly. This layer consists of the axons of rods and cones which synapse with dendrites of bipolar neurons and horizontal cells.

questions.text:
Match the following

Column A

  1. Primary survey
  2. Secondary survey
  3. Definitive care
  4. Resuscitation


Column B

  1. Make a management plan
  2. Identify what can cause death
  3. Identify other injuries
  4. Treat what can cause death
questions.solution:
The correct match is¬†

  1. Primary survey¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†B. Identify what can cause death
  2. Secondary survey¬† ¬†C. Identify other injuries
  3. Definitive care.¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†A. Make a management plan
  4. Resuscitation¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† D. Treat what can cause death

¬†

Related Pearl: ATLS Primary Survey

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

Primary Survey: ABCDEs of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate) - If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment - maintain adequate oxygenation, consider non-invasive or invasive ventilation when indicated
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage, maintain circulating volume and adequate end-organ perfusion) - Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment - perform a basic neurologic evaluation (AVPU/GCS-P), blood glucose levels
  • Exposure with environmental control - undress the patient and examine thoroughly for possible injuries, prevent hypothermia

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood collection - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x-rays must also be done on pregnant women.
  • (e)FAST

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for _____
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of Ayre’s spatula which is used for preparing PAP smear. The Papanicolaou test (Pap test) is a screening test for cervical cancer. 

The squamocolumnar junction is scraped using Ayre's spatula by rotating it around the cervix. The obtained scrapings are spread evenly onto a glass slide and immediately fixed in a solution of 95% ethyl alcohol and ether. After 30 minutes of fixation, the slide is air-dried and then stained with Pap or a short stain method. 

Prerequisites for Pap smear testing:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • The ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have had intercourse in the 24hrs prior to the test. 

Screening guidelines:

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Women aged 21-29 years: Pap test every 3 years
  • Women who are aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing (co-test) every 5 years or Pap alone every 3 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.

A. Giving knowledge and Information to the Patient 

B. Setting up the Interview

C. Addressing the Patient’s emotions with empathic responses

D. Assessing the Patient’s perception
questions.solution:

  2. Assessing the Patient’s perception
  3. Obtaining the Patient’s invitation
  4. Giving knowledge and Information to the Patient

questions.text:
Match the following:
Column A Column B
Omalizumab Anti-CD6
Daclizumab Anti-CD25
Itolizumab Anti-IGE
Belimumab Anti-IgG1
¬† Anti-B cell activator
questions.solution:
Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE used in the treatment of bronchial asthma.

Itolizumab is a drug used in the treatment of psoriasis which acts by inhibiting CD6. Itolizumab down-regulates the production of multiple pro-inflammatory cytokines such as interferon, Interleukin-6, and TNF.

Daclizumab is an IL2R antagonist which binds to CD25. It is used as an immunosuppressant in adults with the relapsing type of Multiple sclerosis. It is contraindicated in those with liver disease as it causes severe liver injury, including autoimmune hepatitis and liver failure. Another drug that prevents IL-2R mediated T-cell activation is basiliximab.

Belimumab is a B-lymphocyte stimulator (BLyS)-specific inhibitor indicated for the treatment of adult patients with active, autoantibody-positive, systemic lupus erythematosus who are receiving standard therapy.

Related Pearl: Monoclonal antibodies nomenclature

Murine - 0% human: “omab” (Tositumomab)

Chimeric - 65% human: “ximab” (Rituximab)

Humanized - 95% human: “zumab” (Trastuzumab)

Fully human - 100% human: “umab” (Adalimumab)

questions.text: What is pegloticase used for?
questions.solution:
Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase). It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite.

It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

questions.text: Myosin head detaches from actin by which of the following mechanism?

choices.text: Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution: Binding of ATP on the free site of myosin leads to the detachment of myosin head from the thin filament.

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.solution:
Phenylbutyrate can be used to reduce ammonia levels in patients with urea cycle disorders.

Phenylbutyrate diverts urea into an alternate pathway and reduces the amount of ammonia. Hence, acting as an ammonia scavenger. Other drugs that can be used to achieve the same outcome (ammonia scavengers) include phenylacetate and benzoate.

Note: Arginine is used as first-line treatment as it provides ornithine; a positive regulator of the urea cycle. Arginine also activates NAG synthase which increases NAG; a positive regulator of the urea cycle

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Jackson-Pratt drain.

Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely drain the air or fluids that may accumulate. They promote wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains can be:

  • Open : They are based on the principle of gravity
  • Semi-open : Their action is based on capillary effect
  • Closed : They carry out their actions through suction

Jackson-pratt drain is a closed, air-tight drainage system that operates by self-suction. The drain is sutured in place on the skin at the site of insertion to promote stability. There are two main parts to a JP drain:

  1. Hollow tube
  2. Collection bulb

The drain should be emptied as often as possible to allow the bulb to be compressed fully in order to maintain suction. This is usually done every 4-6 hours the first few days. 

Other options:

Option A: Hemovac is also a closed type of suction drain which can typically handle larger amounts of fluid than the JP drain.

Option C: Minivac is a closed wound drainage system under negative pressure used in minor surgeries.

Option D: Corrugated drain is an open drainage system to remove excess fluid from the operated site.

questions.text:
The cause of death is noted by which of the following in India?
  1. Sample registration system
  2. Census
  3. Death declaration and medical certificate
  4. Lay reporting
  5. ¬†
questions.solution:
The cause of death is noted by the Sample registration system (SRS), Death certificate and via lay reporting.

Lay reporting is defined as the collection of information, its use, and its transmission to other levels of the health system by non-professional health workers.

SRS was initiated in the mid-1960s to provide reliable estimates of birth and death rates at the National and State levels.

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following:
questions.solution:
Restriction endonucleases can act on AAGCTT.¬†

Restriction endonucleases act and cleave at the site of a¬†palindromic sequence. A palindromic sequence is a sequence that reads the same backward and forward. An example is listed below.

5' --AAGCTT-- 3'
3' --TTCGAA-- 5'

Restriction endonucleases enzymes are routinely used for DNA modification in laboratories, and they are a vital tool in molecular cloning.¬†

questions.text:
Assertion: WHO Recommends Typhoid Vaccine for disaster management in endemic areas.
Reason: Vaccination is a cost-effective method of disaster control.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
The WHO does not recommend typhoid, cholera or tetanus vaccines for the general population after a disaster. However, healthcare workers are recommended to take these vaccines.

Supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta are the most practical and effective strategies of preventing diseases, post-disaster.

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product?
questions.solution:
When glutamine is replaced by asparagine, there is no change in the function of the protein product.

This is due to the concept of conservative or homologous replacement of amino acids. Asparagine and glutamine are both uncharged polar (hydrophilic) amino acids. Thus, when glutamine is replaced with asparagine there is no change in the polarity or the charge of the peptide/protein.

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except:
questions.solution:
Babesia is an intracellular parasite of RBCs, not of the hepatocytes.

Its trophozoites invade the RBCs.

The liver is usually not affected as babesia lack an exoerythrocytic phase.

questions.text: The numerator of perinatal mortality rate includes ___________

choices.text: Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g

questions.solution:
Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g is included in the numerator of perinatal mortality rate .

Perinatal mortality rate is described as late foetal and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000 grams at birth expressed as a ratio per 1000 live births weighing over 1000 gram at birth.

questions.text:

  1. Subcapsular hematoma
  2. Injury confined to Gerota‚Äôs fascia
  3. Avulsion of Pelvi-ureteric junction
  4. Shattered kidney
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of renal injuries from least to most severe is is 1-2-3-4.

  1. Subcapsular hematoma
  2. Injury confined to Gerota‚Äôs fascia
  3. Avulsion of Pelvi-ureteric junction
  4. Shattered kidney

The majority of renal injuries are due to blunt trauma.

Contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice to evaluate the renal injuries.

Renal injuries are classified into five grades by "The Organ Injury Scaling system of the American Association for¬†the Surgery of Trauma (AAST)".¬†

The classification of renal injuries is explained in the pearl given below.

questions.text: Which of the following is best method to survey the injection practices of health workers?

choices.text: Direct observation with a structured checklist
In-depth interview with the healthcare provider

questions.solution:
Direct observation with a structured checklist is the best method to survey the injection practices of health workers.

Checklist of practices for assessment or evaluation include:-

  • In order not to harm the patient, each procedure should be administered with a new sterile single-use device, using the right medication, vaccine or fluid for infusion.
  • In order not to expose the provider to any avoidable risk, in general, any needles used during a procedure should be placed in a puncture-proof closed container immediately after use without recapping. In addition, providers of these procedures should be fully vaccinated against Hepatitis-B.
  •  In order that any waste produced during the performance of a procedure does not become a hazard for other people, used sharps waste and infectious non-sharps waste should be safely managed.

World Patient Safety Day is observed every year on September 17th. The theme for the 2020 campaign is "Safe health workers, Safe patients" which focuses on the interrelationship between health worker safety and patient safety. It emphasizes the need for a safe working environment for health workers as a prerequisite for ensuring patient safety.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation after consuming an unknown substance. On examination, his PR - 110bpm, and his pupils were dilated. What did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with dilatation of the pupil indicates Atropa belladonna consumption.

Atropa Belladonna acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

Heroin, morphine, and malathion cause constriction of the pupil.

In the Italian language, belladonna means a pretty woman. In ancient times, women used to instill drops containing atropine into their eyes for producing pupillary dilatation so as to make themselves appear more attractive.

questions.text: Identify the following device.
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a cock-up splint. It is used to manage radial nerve palsy. 

Radial nerve palsy manifests as an inability to dorsiflex the wrist and digits (wrist drop and finger drop). Numbness occurs on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and the dorsal aspect of the radial 3 1/2 digits. The cock-up splint is designed to counteract the wrist drop position by holding the wrist in a slightly extended or neutral position, which helps prevent further contracture and allows for functional use of the hand.

Other options:

Option B: Undisplaced Colles' fracture is managed by immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks. Displaced fractures are managed by manipulative reduction followed by immobilization in Colles' cast in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

Option C: Knuckle bender splint is used in cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated. The splint can be used to correct and prevent metacarpophalangeal hyperextension by maintaining flexion as shown below.

Option D: Dynamic finger splint can be used for:

  • Immobilization in case of fracture of the proximal phalanx 
  • Extensor tendon injuries of the finger
  • Prevention of deformities in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Post-operative immobilization.

questions.text: A patient undergoes surgery of the lateral part of the base of the skull. Postoperatively, the patient presents with aspiration but does not have a change in voice. Which of the following is the reason?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient experiences aspiration but does not exhibit any change in voice following base of skull surgery. This suggests an injury to the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN). 

In SLN injury, only the cricothyroid muscle is involved which is used only in high-pitch vocalization, normal speech will not be affected. SLN also provides sensory supply to the mucosa above vocal cords, hence its lesion would lead to increased susceptibility to aspiration.

Other options:

Option B: The glossopharyngeal nerve does not provide sensory or motor supply to the larynx. 

Option C and D: The patient also has normal vocalization which rules out recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) and high vagal injury. RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid, therefore an RLN lesion would lead to disordered vocalization. A high vagal injury would mean that both the SLN and RLN functions are affected, therefore that can also be ruled out.

Related Pearl: Nerves of Larynx

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text:
Assertion: Malathion is used as an ultra-low volume fogger during epidemics
Reason: Ultra-low volume foggers have no residual effects

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Malathion is used as an ultra low volume fogger during epidemics but it has residual effects(3months).

It is widely used for killing adult mosquitoes to prevent or interrupt dengue-haemorrhagic fever, and mosquito-borne encephalitis epidemics.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: Sacubitril/Valsartan is indicated in the treatment of NYHA class II to IV in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.      

Reason: Sacubitril/Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) counteracts RAAS system and raises the level of vasoactive peptides.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not a correct explain the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
Sacubitril(neprilysin inhibitor)-Valsartan(ARB) is known as ARNI (angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor).

It blocks the RAAS system while raising levels of endogenous vasoactive peptides(natriuretic peptides, bradykinin, adrenomedullin) degraded by neprilysin. (Reason)

It is indicated for use in patients with Chronic NYHA class II to class IV Heart failure (LVEF </= 40%) with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). (Assertion)

It reduces cardiovascular mortality and hospitalization for heart failure as well as all-cause mortality compared to ACE inhibitor alone.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with sensorineural hearing loss and eye defects presents to the OPD with hematuria. His renal biopsy on light microscopy was normal. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had Gr 5 CKD an is undergoing dialysis. Which of the following would be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a child with hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and eye defects¬†with¬†normal renal biopsy¬†is consistent with Alport Syndrome. It is a hereditary nephritis, which explains the family history of chronic kidney disease.¬†

Alport syndrome¬†is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the¬†COL4A5¬†gene, which codes for the alpha chain of type IV collagen. In approximately 85% of cases, the syndrome is X-linked.

In the early years (around 5 years), patients are often asymptomatic but may have persistent microscopic hematuria. Between 5 and 10 years of age, proteinuria, and hypertension may develop, which can be managed with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. By 10 years of age, serum creatinine levels start to rise. Around 15 years, patients may experience ear, nose, and throat (ENT) manifestations, with high-frequency sensory neural hearing loss being a common feature in males. Ocular manifestations, such as anterior lenticonus (pathognomonic) and dot and fleck retinopathy (most common), typically appear around the age of 20. Anterior lenticonus is particularly correlated with the development of end-stage renal disease (ESRD).¬†By 25 to 30 years of age, most individuals with Alport's syndrome progress to ESRD.

Gross hematuria following upper respiratory tract infections is not typically seen in Alport's syndrome and should prompt consideration of other conditions, such as IgA nephropathy.

Skin immunofluorescence to demonstrate the lack of the Œ±5(IV) collagen chain and genetic testing can be used for the diagnosis. Light microscopy and immunofluorescence (IF) on renal biopsy may be normal. Electron microscopy reveals irregular areas of thinning and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), along with splitting of the lamina densa, giving it a basket-weave appearance.

The mainstay of management is the control of hypertension and ACE inhibitors to slow down the progression of renal damage. Although transplant recipients develop anti-GBM antibodies, graft survival is good.

Thin GBM disease is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by persistent microscopic hematuria but no progression to ESRD or extrarenal manifestations. EM can be used to confirm the diagnosis, showing GBM thickness of less than 200 nm.

Other options:

Option B: Goodpasture syndrome is an¬†immune-mediated disease with antibodies against the alpha-3 chain of GBM type IV collagen; it is not hereditary and the light microscopy would reveal extra capillary proliferation with crescents & necrosis.

Option C: In IgA Nephropathy, light microscopy¬†would reveal focal mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis & mesangial widening.

Option D:¬† In post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), there will be diffuse endocapillary proliferation and accompanying leukocytic infiltration seen in light microscopy.

¬†

questions.text:
Match the following:
Column A Column B
A - flat, pigmented birthmarks. Sprengel deformity
B - upward elevation of the scapula Marfan’s syndrome
C - wrist sign Osteogenesis imperfecta
D - Osteopenia and recurrent fractures Neurofibromatosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is

A - 4. Neurofibromatosis

B - 1. Sprengel Deformity

C - 2. Marfan's Syndrome

D - 3. Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 

 

Image A: Image Shows multiple café-au-lait spots distributed over the back. Neurofibromatosis is usually associated with Café au lait spots which are flat, pigmented birthmarks.

Image B: The image shows an upward elevation of the scapula relative to the thoracic cage characteristically seen in Sprengel deformity.

Sprengel deformity is a congenital upward elevation of the scapula. It is due to the failure of the scapula to descend completely in embryonic life. The affected scapula is smaller, shaped differently, abnormally high, and somewhat prominent. Shoulder movements are usually painless.

Abduction and elevation of shoulders may be limited due to the fixation of the scapula.

The Cavendish classification is used to grade the severity of Sprengel deformity.

Management: If the deformity is mild, no treatment is required. In severe deformity, surgery may be indicated. These procedures include:

  • Green procedure
  • Woodward procedure
  • Mears procedure

Image C: The given image is suggestive of Marfan's syndrome.

  • Marfan's syndrome patients have characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist.
  • This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly).
  • A few patients have severe joint hypermobility similar to Ehler Danlos syndrome.

Image D: The X-ray is characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as "brittle bone" disease, is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal synthesis and structural defects of the type I collagen leading to abnormalities of the bones, teeth, ligaments, sclerae, and skin.

The defining clinical features of OI include:

  • Osteopenia
  • Recurrent Fractures
  • Laxity of Ligaments
  • Bluish Discoloration of The Sclerae
  • Dentinogenesis Imperfecta ("Crumbling Teeth")

questions.text: Tafenoquine is used in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Treatment of malaria in children <2 years

questions.solution:
Tafenoquine is used in the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax. Total eradication of plasmodium species which includes clinical curative and hypnozoites phase are called radical cure.

Primaquine and tafenoquine (derivative of primaquine) have very high activity against the latent tissue forms (hypnozoites) of the species. It is primarily used for the chemoprophylaxis and radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about tedizolid?
questions.solution:
Tedizolid is active against gram-positive organisms. 

Tedizolid belongs to the class of oxazolidinones. It has poor activity against most gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes. It inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the P site of the 50S ribosomal subunit.

It is used for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections, respiratory tract infections caused by streptococci, and S. aureus including MRSA.

Common adverse effects include myelosuppression leading to anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and pancytopenia.

questions.text: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
DMT1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte.

Dietary iron is mostly in Fe3+ (ferric state) and must be reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous state) by ferrireductases. Fe2+ iron destined for circulation is transported from the cytoplasm across the basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin 1.

Hephaestin is an iron oxidase that converts Fe2+ to Fe3+

questions.text: If the lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be?
questions.solution:
If lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be minimum volume as the opposing force by the chest wall would be non existant. 

The yellow line in the above graph denotes the compliance of lungs alone. According to the graph, when the pressure (x axis)  inside the lung is zero, there is some volume of air lesser than FRC still present (y axis) inside the lungs which is less than the functional residual capacity and residual volume which can be called as minimum volume.

questions.text: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is fornix which is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

The anteromedial central branches from the anterior cerebral artery supply the fornix along with optic chiasma, lamina terminalis, hypothalamus, para-olfactory areas, and cingulate gyrus.

questions.text: A 25-year old man presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown below. All of the following are true regarding the likely etiology except?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows gram-negative diplococci within the polymorphs, characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Neisseria is not an obligate intracellular organism, it can also occur extracellularly i.e, it is¬†a facultative intracellular organism.¬†The other neisseria that are found as normal inhabitants of the human respiratory tract occur extracellularly.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative, non-sporulating, non-motile diplococcus that is¬†aerobic¬†but may grow anaerobically also. It is oxidase and catalase-positive.

Although Neisseria are¬†non-motile organisms, they show¬†twitching motility. This¬†is a flagella-independent form of bacterial translocation over moist surfaces that occurs by the extension and retraction of polar type IV pili. These¬†pili act as virulence factors by promoting attachment to host cells and inhibiting phagocytosis.

Virulence factors for gonococci:

  1. Outer Membrane Proteins (OMPs)
  2. IgA proteases
  3. Pili
  4. Lipo-oligosaccharide (LOS)
  5. Transferrin
  6. Lactoferrin-binding protein

questions.text: A polysaccharide vaccine against Streptococcus pneumoniae has 23 serotypes. In which of the following patients is this vaccine most beneficial?

choices.text: A patient with sickle cell disease
A patient with recurrent otitis media

questions.solution:
The polysaccharide vaccine against Streptococcus pneumoniae (PPSV-23) is most beneficial for patients with sickle cell disease.

S. pneumoniae is an encapsulated organism that is detected by the spleen and is removed. However, in sickle cell disease, the sickled cells block the vessels in the spleen which results in splenic infarction. This hyposplenism results in an increased risk of pneumococcal infection. Hence, pneumococcal vaccine (PPSV-23) is given to these patients as a prophylactic measure to reduce this risk.

questions.text:
Assertion and Reason:
Assertion:-
Ultrasonography is the primary imaging modality for the screening and diagnosis of IVH and parenchymal hemorrhage in neonates.
Reason:-
The posterior fontanelle offers a good acoustic window for imaging using USG.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true statements but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false statement
Assertion is false but the reason is true statement
Both assertion and reason are false statement

questions.solution:
Ultrasonography is the primary imaging modality for the screening and diagnosis of IVH and parenchymal hemorrhage in neonates because of the ideal acoustic window offered by the anterior(not posterior) fontanelle, easy and quick image acquisition at the bedside, and a lack of radiation hazard.

All neonates at high risk for IVH, i.e gestational age <32 weeks or birth weight <1500 g should undergo screening. More mature preterm infants (32-34 wks) should also be screened if they experience a turbulent postnatal course in the form of shock requiring inotropes, unexplained anemia, or severe RDS requiring mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A patient of anorexia nervosa was eating all her meals according to the prescribed diet chart but there is no change in her weight after 1 week. Which of the following needs to be done?

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.solution:
Observe the patient for 2 hours post-meal because the patient might vomit the food.

Treatment of anorexia nervosa:

  • Hospitalization: 
    • Patients with a weight 20% less than expected weight for height should be considered for hospitalization. 
    • Dur­ing a hospitalized treatment program, patients should be weighed daily, early in the morning after emptying the bladder.
    • The daily fluid intake and urine output should be recorded.
    • If vomiting is occurring, hospital staff members must monitor serum electrolyte levels regularly and watch for the development of hypokalemia.
    • Because food is often regurgitated after meals, the staff may be able to control vomiting by making the bathroom inaccessible for at least 2 hours after meals or by having an attendant in the bathroom to prevent the opportunity for vomiting.
  • Psychotherapy: 
    • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
    • Dynamic psychotherapy
    • Family therapy
  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Pharmacological agents are not the first-line treatment but cypro­heptadine, amitriptyline, clomipramine, pimozide, and chlorproma­zine show some improvement in these patients.
    • Trials of fluoxetine have resulted in some reports of weight gain.

questions.text: What is bullet wipe?
questions.solution:
Bullet wipe is due to the grease, soot or debris from the barrel of the gun.

While examining the clothing of a victim of bullet injury, there is a deposition of various residues surrounding the entrance defect at various ranges known as Bullet wipe. It helps in determining the wounds of inlet and outlet upon the body.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a COPD patient in ICU developing palpitations and the ECG showing narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with more than three different P wave morphologies, points to the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image) with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness. The clinical features are most commonly related to the underlying precipitating illness (COPD in this case). Unlike atrial fibrillation, there are clear isoelectric intervals between P waves.

Treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities is the mainstay of treatment. Electrical cardioversion has no effect.

The calcium-channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem may slow the atrial and ventricular rate. MAT may respond to amiodarone, but long-term therapy with this agent is usually avoided due to its toxicities, particularly in pulmonary fibrosis.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The provided history of falling on an outstretched arm and the X-ray revealing an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint point to the diagnosis of Galeazzi's fracture.

Galeazzi's fracture is the fracture of the lower third of the radius and the subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This injury usually happens when one falls on an outstretched hand. 

Patients present with pain, swelling, and deformity at the lower end of the radius. On examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign). 

The aim of treatment for this fracture is to preserve supination and pronation of the forearm. In children, closed reduction is usually enough to achieve perfect reduction. However, in adults, open reduction using a k-wire fixation or compression plating is usually required. It is also important to look for ulnar nerve damage.

Galeazzi's fracture can cause complications such as malunion due to displacement of the fragment. This often results in deformity and limitation in supination and pronation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text:
Match the following:
Column A Column B
Box car Nuclei Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Myocyte disarray Hypertension
Vacuolation in myocyte Dilated Cardiomyopathy
Myocyte hypertrophy Subendocardial ischemia
  Hypersensitivity myocarditis
questions.solution:
Column A Column B
Boxcar Nuclei Hypertension
Myocyte disarray Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 
Vacuolation in myocyte

Subendocardial ischemia
Myocyte hypertrophy Dilated Cardiomyopathy

 

- Myocyte vacuolization, also called myocytolysis is associated with Subendocardial ischemia.

- In hypertensive heart disease, the individual myocytes are enlarged and show nucleomegaly. This is called as Box Car Nuclei.

- The most important histologic features of HOCM myocardium are:

  1. Massive myocyte hypertrophy
  2. Haphazard disarray of bundles of myocytes, individual myocytes, and contractile elements in sarcomeres within cells. This is termed myofiber disarray.
  3. Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

- Though myocyte hypertrophy is possible in both hypertrophic cardiomyopathy(HOCM) and dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), considering the fact that myocyte disarray matches HOCM, while no other options match DCM, the answer, by elimination, becomes DCM.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true with respect to CTEV?
  1. 50% of cases are bilateral 
  2. More common in males
  3. The forefoot is adducted and supinated
  4. Ponsetti technique has a correction rate of about 90%
  5. The correction of equinus is made first
questions.solution:
The correction of equinus is made last, not first, according to Ponsetti’s method. 

CTEV is a hindfoot deformity involving the calcaneotalarnavicular complex.

Ponseti's method is the currently used method for conservative management of CTEV. Previously Kite's method was followed.

 

 

  Ponseti's method Kite's method
Treatment start <2 weeks 1 month
Order of correction cavus -adduction - varus- equinus adduction - inversion -equinus
Fulcrum  Head of the talus Calcaneocuboid joint
POP type Above knee cast Below knee cast
Duration 6-8 weeks 6-9 months

 

The male-to-female ratio is 2:1 and bilateral involvement is found in 30-50% of cases

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
A patient comatose due to stroke in the past few hours should be intubated because of an increased risk of aspiration pneumonia. Following a stroke, the patient is at an increased risk of aspiration because of impaired swallowing response and gag reflex.

There is no increased risk of developing sleep apnoea following stroke. So, the assertion is true but the reason is false.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as True or False regarding CPR
  1. CPR can be administered irrespective of rib fracture 
  2. Chest compression at the rate of 100-120/min in adults and 90/min in neonates and infants 
  3. In adult CPR even with 2 rescuers, compression ventilation ratio is 30:2 
  4. In infant CPR, ratio changes to 15:2 from 30:2 when there is a second rescuer
  5. If AED is available, give defibrillation and chest compression alternately every 3 minutes.
questions.solution:
1. CPR can be administered irrespective of rib fracture - True
  2. Chest compression at the rate of 100-120/min in adults and 90/min in neonates and infants - False
  3. In adult CPR even with 2 rescuers, compression ventilation ratio is 30:2 - True
  4. In infant CPR, ratio changes to 15:2 from 30:2 when there is a second rescuer - True
  5. If AED is available, give defibrillation and chest compression alternately every 3 minutes. - False

 

  • CPR can be continued even with rib fractures. 
  • Irrespective of Age, compressions are 100-120/min
  • In adult CPR even with 2 rescuers, compression ventilation ratio is 30:2 
  • In infant CPR, ratio changes to 15:2 from 30:2 when there is a second rescuer
  • If AED is available, give defibrillation and chest compression alternately every 2 minutes

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false regarding Subacute Sclerosing Pan Encephalitis:
  1. Occurs as sequelae following infection with VZV
  2. Seizures, personality changes, and myoclonus is the presentation
  3. EEG shows a periodic sharp wave pattern
  4. Presents 8 - 10 years after initial infection
  5. Antibodies against the virus are found in CSF
questions.solution:
• Occurs as sequelae following infection with VZV - False

It occurs as a late sequela, presenting 5-15 years following measles infection, not VZV.

  • Seizures, personality changes, and myoclonus is the presentation - True

Initial poor school performance and mood and personality changes occur. As the disease progresses, patients develop progressive intellectual deterioration, focal and/or generalized seizures, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual disturbances. In the late stage of the illness, patients are unresponsive, quadriparetic, and spastic, with hyperactive tendon reflexes and extensor plantar responses.

  • EEG shows a periodic sharp wave pattern - True

The EEG may initially show only nonspecific slowing, but with disease progression, patients develop a characteristic periodic pattern with bursts of high-voltage, sharp, slow waves every 3–8 s, followed by periods of attenuated (“flat”) background.

  • Presents 8 - 10 years after initial infection - True

It occurs as late sequelae, presenting 5-15 years following measles infection

  • Antibodies against the virus are found in CSF - True

CSF anti-measles antibody levels are invariably elevated, and oligoclonal anti-measles antibodies are often present. The measles virus can be cultured from brain tissue using special cocultivation techniques. Viral antigen can be identified immunocytochemically, and the viral genome can be detected by in situ hybridization or PCR amplification.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not associated with superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome?
questions.solution:
Sensorineural hearing loss is not seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS). They may experience mild to moderate hearing conductive loss.

Conductive hearing loss is due to the abnormal transmission and dissipation of acoustic energy through the defect (third window), leading to reduced conduction to the cochlea for lower frequencies. This can manifest as a low-frequency air-bone gap at multiple frequencies. There is no defect in the cochlea or the auditory pathway.

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD) is a condition in which bone between the apex of the superior semicircular canal and the middle cranial fossa is absent. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. 

Patients may have vestibular symptoms like vertigo triggered by loud sounds (Tullio phenomenon)or pressure such as coughing and can also experience hyperacusis for bone-conducted sounds. They may perceive the sounds of their own eye movements or footsteps in the affected ear. 

The patients may exhibit nystagmus when exposed to loud sounds or during the Valsalva maneuver or pressure in the ear canal (positive fistula test). The direction of the nystagmus aligns with the affected superior semicircular canal, and some patients may tilt their heads in the plane of the affected superior semicircular canal in response to loud sounds.  

Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect. The click-evoked VEMP (vestibular evoked myogenic potential) response and vestibuloocular reflex are pronounced in SSCD patients, in which the evoked eye movements align with the affected superior canal. 

For mild symptoms, avoidance of triggers is recommended. In case of severe disabling symptoms, surgical resurfacing of the superior semicircular canal or plugging of the superior semicircular canal may be attempted.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is non-pulsatile dosing of GnRH agonist not used?
questions.solution:
Pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in the treatment of male infertility.

Pulsatile administration of GnRH agonists results in increased FSH and LH secretion and is used to treat male and female infertility.

Non-pulsatile or continuous dose of GnRH agonist results in suppression and decreased concentrations of gonadotropins LH and FSH. They are used in:

  1. Endometriosis
  2. Uterine fibroids
  3. Central precocious puberty
  4. Ca prostate
  5. Ca ovary and breast
  6. Controlled ovary stimulation

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to:
questions.solution:
Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

Prolonged exposure to elevated levels of vasopressin (ADH) leads eventually to downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors. This prevents excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH levels and hence maintains euvolemia. This is known as vasopressin escape. This helps prevent excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH. 

Related Pearl: Types of vasopressin receptors and their functions

Receptor Localization Functions
V1a
  • Vascular smooth muscle
  • Platelets
  • Hepatocytes
  • Myometrium
  • Vasoconstriction
  • Platelet aggregation
  • Glycogenolysis
  • Uterine contraction
V3/V1b 
  • Anterior pituitary
  • ACTH release
V2
  • Basolateral membrane of collecting tubule
  • Vascular endothelium
  • Vascular  smooth muscle
  • Upregulation of Aqp2
  • vwF & factor 8 release
  • Vasodilation

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false
  1. Methazolamide causes a decrease in ocular blood flow 
  2. Latanoprost is used with caution in patients with bronchial asthma
  3. Topiramate can cause bilateral angle-closure glaucoma 
  4. Central Scotoma is seen in open-angle glaucoma 
  5. Latanoprost causes a reversible increase of iris pigmentation
questions.solution:
• Methazolamide causes a decrease in ocular blood flow - False

Methazolamide causes an increase in ocular blood flow.

  • Latanoprost is used with caution in patients with bronchial asthma - False 

Latanoprost is used with caution in those with uveitis, iritis, cystoid macular edema, and herpes simplex keratitis. Not in bronchial asthma. Latanoprost is the most commonly used glaucoma medication and is used for ocular hypertension and open-angle glaucoma. It can result in increased iris pigmentation with time. Other side effects include lash growth, allergic conjunctival hyperemia, and orbital fat atrophy 

  • Topiramate can cause bilateral angle-closure glaucoma - True

 The antiseizure drug topiramate can cause choroidal effusions leading to angle-closure glaucoma.

  • Central Scotoma is commonly seen in primary open-angle glaucoma - False

 Early nasal step, temporal wedge, or paracentral scotoma are the more commonly seenScotomas in primary open-angle glaucoma

  • Latanoprost causes a reversible increase of iris pigmentation - False

 The increase in pigmentation due to latanoprost is irreversible

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in SCID?
questions.solution:
BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia and not SCID (severe combined immunodeficiency).

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. In this condition, the following genes are involved:

  • JAK3
  • RAG1
  • IL-7R

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including: 

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the ICU. While taking a blood sample for ABG, which of the following steps would you not do?

choices.text: Normal ph can't rule out acid base disorder
Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood
If modified Allens test is negative, alternate site is chosen
Radial artery is the preferred site

questions.solution:
0.5 ml of Heparin is not added to the syringe before taking blood.

Very little heparin is needed in the sample to prevent clotting; 0.05 to 0.10 ml of a dilute solution will help prevent coagulation of 1 ml of blood without affecting its pH. This is achieved by drawing 0.5 ml into the syringe and flushing it out. The residue that remains adherent to the syringe is sufficient for the procedure.

Heparin must be added to the syringe as an anticoagulant. Because the pH of heparin is near 7.0, and the Po2 and Pco2 of the heparin solution are near room air values, excess heparin can alter ABG measurements. After flushing the syringe with heparin, a sufficient amount usually remains in the dead space of the syringe and needle for anticoagulation without distortion of the ABG determination.

Note: 

  • Modified Allen's test positive indicates that the collateral blood flow is normal
  • Modified Allen's test negative indicates that the collateral blood flow is abnormal and an alternate site must be chosen.

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except:
questions.solution:
Enhancer deletion does not convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.

Mechanisms of activating oncogenes:

Mechanism Activation of oncogenes
Mutation Mutation activates the gene. A classic example is the point mutation of the RAS oncogene.
Promoter insertion  Insertion of a viral promoter region near a gene activates it.
Enhancer insertion  Insertion of a viral enhancer region near a gene activates it.
Chromosomal translocation  One chromosome is split off and joined to another. An example is the Philadelphia chromosome.
Gene amplification   Abnormal multiplication of a gene resulting in many copies. This can occur with oncogenes and genes involved in tumor drug resistance.

questions.text:
Theme and Focus - Substance Abuse

Option List

  1. Alcohol
  2. Cannabis
  3. Cocaine
  4. Opioids
  5. Amphetamine
  6. Ketamine
  7. LSD

 

i. A 27-year-old male presents to the ER with tremors, diaphoresis, auditory and visual hallucinations. He is not oriented to time, place or person. Examination reveals hypertension, tachycardia, and hepatomegaly. Which of the following substances is likely?

 

ii. A 32-year-old male presents with yawning, diarrhea and diaphoresis. On examination, you notice mydriasis, fever - 104 Degrees Fahrenheit, rhinorrhea and piloerections. Which of the following substances is likely?
questions.solution:
Case 1

The given clinical scenario of disorientation, hallucination with features of autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, diaphoresis), hepatomegaly is suggestive of delirium tremens.Delirium tremens is the most severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs usually within 3-4 days of alcohol withdrawal.Characteristic features are:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
  • Poor attention and distractibility
  • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and very frightening
  • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, sweating and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia


Case 2

The probable substance of abuse is opioid. Opioid withdrawal usually starts with feelings of anxiety, yawning, lacrimation, diaphoresis, rhinorrhea, and diffuse myalgias progressing to piloerection, mydriasis, nausea, profuse vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal cramping. Treatment of opioid withdrawal

  • Symptoms of opioid withdrawal can be rendered more tolerable by the administration of the central α2-agonist clonidine, antiemetics, and antidiarrheal agents.

  • Daily administration of a verified dose of methadone PO is recommended to inhibit withdrawal symptoms and reduce craving.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features
Alcohol
Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: The test performed in the following video is
questions.solution:
The test performed in the given video is Allen's test.

Allen's test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

Procedure:

  • The radial and ulnar arteries are occluded as the patient makes a tight fist so as to exsanguinate the palm.
  • Then the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released.

Interpretation:

  • As occlusion of the ulnar artery is released, the color of the open palm is observed. Normally, the color will return to the palm within 5 – 6 seconds.
  • If the palm remains pale for more than 6-10 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow.
  • The modified Allen’s test considers a threshold of 5 to 15 seconds.

Clinical significance:

  • In recent years, studies have shown that, although the Allen test is often used to identify patients at increased risk for ischemic complications from radial artery cannulation, the predictive value of this test is poor.
  • It is also used for identifying patients acceptable for radial artery harvest or use for coronary angiography.

questions.text:
Match the Following:
Column A Column B
1. Madelung deformity A. Cubitus varus
2. Haglund deformity B. Cubitus valgus
3. Buttonhole deformity C. Rheumatoid arthritis
4. Gunstock deformity D. Volar ulnar deviation
  E. Calcaneal enlargement
questions.solution:
Madelung deformity is an abnormality of the palmar ulnar part of the distal radial physis. In this, progressive ulnar and volar tilt develops at the distal articular surface of the radius with distal ulna dorsal subluxation.

Haglund deformity, pump bump or Mulholland deformity is seen in the ankle joint. It is a bony enlargement formed at the posterosuperior aspect of the calcaneum.

It is caused due to the chronic inflammation of the retrocalcaneal bursa. Recurrent pressure from the shoe may lead to the chronic inflammation of the bursa and calcification at the site of insertion of the Achilles tendon.

Malunion following supracondylar fracture most commonly leads to cubitus varus which is known as gunstock deformity.

Boutonnière deformity is also called as button hole deformity.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: ABCDE rule applies for:
questions.solution:
ABCDE algorithm is used to diagnose melanoma.

It comprises of:

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variegation
  • Diameter of more than 6 mm 
  • Evolution or change


Melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though it represents only 4% of skin cancers, it accounts for 80% of deaths (high mortality rate). It presents as a pigmented lesion that has enlarged, ulcerated, or bled.

Histopathological confirmation is the gold standard in the diagnosis of melanoma. It is divided into four main types: nodular melanoma (NM), superficial spreading melanoma (SSM), lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM), and acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM). 

The treatment consists of wide local excision of the tumor and follow-up to detect any local recurrence around the scar and excluding nodal spread.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Related Pearl: Breslow‚Äôs Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

Related Pearl: Main Prognostic Factors for Primary Melanoma

The following are the prognostic factors for primary melanoma (predictive value from *** high to * low):

  • Thickness (Breslow index)***
  • Sentinel node status***
  • Ulceration**
  • Mitotic rate** (negative value especially in thin tumours)
  • Regression* (underestimation of Breslow)
  • Age* (negative for older age)
  • Sex* (negative for males)
  • Location* (negative for head and neck)

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy?
  1. Polygenic inheritance
  2. Lamotrigine helps control myoclonic jerks
  3. Benzodiazepines can be used as monotherapy for myoclonic jerks
  4. Valproate is not useful for the treatment
questions.solution:
Valproate is the drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. 
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome) is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults. It may be caused due to mutation in many genes, which include:

  • CACNB4
  • CLNC2
  • EJM2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9
  • GABRA1
  • GABRD
  • Myoclonin1/ EFHC1

It typically first manifests itself between the ages of 12 and 18. It presents with brief episodes of involuntary muscle twitching occurring early in the morning after awakening. They can be provoked by sleep deprivation. They usually respond well to anticonvulsant medication.

Most patients also have generalized seizures that affect the entire brain and many also have absence seizures.

The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike–and–slow- wave discharges.

Valproate is the drug of choice, while other drugs such as levetiracetam, zonisamide, topiramate, and lamotrigine are also effective. Clonazepam can be used as a monotherapy or an adjunct in the treatment of the Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (petit mal variant), akinetic and myoclonic seizures.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of women with fishy odor vaginal discharge is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV). The microscopic finding is vaginal epithelial cells with bacteria attached to their surface called clue cells, creating a poorly defined cellular border. They are the most reliable indicators of BV. 

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by a decrease in lactobacilli and an overgrowth of anaerobic bacterial species, including gardnerella, prevotella,mobiluncus, and bacteroides. Multiple or new sexual partners, having female partners, and engaging in oral sex are associated with a higher risk of BV. They may experience a foul-smelling (fishy odor) thin vaginal discharge. 

The clinical diagnosis of BV is based on the presence of three out of four Amsel criteria: elevated vaginal pH (>4.5), thin noninflammatory discharge, >20% clue cells, and a fishy odor (positive whiff test) after adding 10% potassium hydroxide to a vaginal sample. creating a poorly defined cellular border. 

BV is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes such as preterm birth, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and postpartum endometritis. It also increases susceptibility to sexually transmitted infections, including HIV.

The recommended treatment options in nonpregnant women include oral metronidazole, metronidazole gel, or clindamycin cream. Alternative options include oral secnidazole, tinidazole, or clindamycin. Partner treatment is not needed.
